11th Mathematics Knowledge Competition for Students of Secondary Technical and Vocational Schools National Competition, April 16, 2011

| $\mathrm{N} 1$ | $\mathrm{~N} 2$ | $\mathrm{~N} 3$ | $\mathrm{~N} 4$ | $\mathrm{~N} 5$ |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
|  |  |  |  |  | -/
theorem algebra_143454 {x y : ℝ} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0) :
    ((Real.sqrt x + Real.sqrt y)^2 - (Real.sqrt x^3 - Real.sqrt y^3) / (Real.sqrt x - Real.sqrt y)) /
    Real.sqrt (x * y) = 1 := by

informal_statement: What is the value of $\frac12\cdot\frac41\cdot\frac18\cdot\frac{16}{1} \dotsm \frac{1}{512}\cdot\frac{1024}{1}$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- What is the value of $\frac12\cdot\frac41\cdot\frac18\cdot\frac{16}{1} \dotsm \frac{1}{512}\cdot\frac{1024}{1}$? -/
theorem algebra_11225 : ∏ i ∈ range 512, (i + 1) / (2 ^ (i + 1)) = 32 := by

soln_description:
Expand both sides of equation (54), and let $s_{1}=a+b+c, s_{2}=b c+c a+a b$, noting that $a b c=1$, we can obtain
$$s_{1}^{2} s_{2}-3 s_{1}^{2}-3 s_{2}^{2}+5 s_{1}+6 s_{2}-6 \geqslant 0$$

Thus, to prove equation (54), it is sufficient to prove equation (1). Below, we will prove equation (1) in two cases.
i) If $s_{1} \geqslant s_{2}$, then
$$\text { the left side of equation (1) } \begin{aligned}
\geqslant & s_{1}^{2} s_{2}-3 s_{1}^{2}-3 s_{2}^{2}+11 s_{2}-6= \\
& \left(s_{2}-3\right)\left(s_{1}^{2}-3 s_{2}+2\right)\left(\text { noting that } s_{2} \geqslant 3, s_{1}^{2} \geqslant 3 s_{2}\right) \geqslant \\
& 0
\end{aligned}$$

In this case, equation (54) holds.
ii) If $s_{2} \geqslant s_{1}$, then
$$\begin{array}{c}
\text { equation (1) } \Leftrightarrow 3 s_{2}^{2}-\left(s_{1}^{2}+6\right) s_{2}+\left(3 s_{1}^{2}-5 s_{1}+6\right) \leqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow \frac{s_{1}^{2}+6-\sqrt{\Delta}}{6} \leqslant s_{2} \\
s_{2} \leqslant \frac{s_{1}^{2}+6+\sqrt{\Delta}}{6}
\end{array}$$

where $\Delta=s_{1}^{4}-24 s_{1}^{2}+60 s_{1}-36$.
Since
$$\begin{array}{l}
s_{1}^{4}-24 s_{1}^{2}+60 s_{1}-36-\left(s_{1}^{2}-2 s_{1}\right)^{2}= \\
4 s_{1}^{3}-28 s_{1}^{2}+60 s_{1}-36= \\
4\left(s_{1}-3\right)^{2}\left(s_{1}-1\right)\left(\text { noting that } s_{1} \geqslant 3\right) \geqslant 0
\end{array}$$

we get $\Delta \geqslant s_{1}^{2}-2 s_{1}>0$, thus, to prove equations (2) and (3), it is sufficient to prove
$$\frac{s_{1}^{2}+6-\left(s_{1}^{2}-2 s_{1}\right)}{6} \leqslant s_{2} \leqslant \frac{s_{1}^{2}+6+\left(s_{1}^{2}-2 s_{1}\right)}{6}$$

i.e.,
$$\begin{array}{c}
\frac{s_{1}+3}{3} \leqslant s_{2} \\
s_{2} \leqslant \frac{s_{1}^{2}-s_{1}+3}{3}
\end{array}$$

By $s_{2} \geqslant s_{1} \geqslant 3$, equation (4) holds, thus equation (2) holds; below we prove equation (5) holds, i.e.,
$$s_{1}^{2}-s_{1}-3 s_{2}+3 \geqslant 0$$

By $s_{3}=1, s_{1}^{3}-4 s_{1} s_{2}+9 s_{3} \geqslant 0$ (see Chapter 1 "Proving Inequalities by Equivalent Transformation" Example 14), we get
$$s_{2} \leqslant \frac{s_{1}^{3}+9}{4 s_{1}}$$

Therefore, to prove equation (6), it is sufficient to prove
$$\begin{array}{c}
\frac{s_{1}^{2}-s_{1}+3}{3} \geqslant \frac{s_{1}^{3}+9}{4 s_{1}} \Leftrightarrow s_{1}^{3}-4 s_{1}^{2}+12 s_{1}-27 \geqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow \\
\left(s_{1}-3\right)\left(s_{1}^{2}-s_{1}+9\right) \geqslant 0
\end{array}$$

By $s_{1} \geqslant 3$, it is easy to see that the above inequality holds, thus proving equation (6), hence when $s_{2} \geqslant s_{1}$, equation (54) also holds.
In summary, equation (54) holds, and the conditions for equality are easily known from the proof process.
Note If in equation (54) we make the substitution: $a \rightarrow b c, b \rightarrow c a, c \rightarrow a b$, then we get
$$(b+c)(c+a)(a+b)(b c+c a+a b) \geqslant 3\left(1+a^{2}\right)\left(1+b^{2}\right)\left(1+c^{2}\right)$$

where $a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}^{+}$, and $a b c=1$. Equality in equation (55) holds if and only if $a=b=c=1$.
informal_statement:
Example 36 (Self-created problem, 2006.12.2) Let \(a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}^{+}\), and \(abc=1\), then
$$(b+c)(c+a)(a+b)(a+b+c) \geqslant 3\left(1+a^{2}\right)\left(1+b^{2}\right)\left(1+c^{2}\right)$$

Equality in (54) holds if and only if \(a=b=c=1\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 36 (Self-created problem, 2006.12.2) Let \(a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}^{+}\), and \(abc=1\), then
$$(b+c)(c+a)(a+b)(a+b+c) \geqslant 3\left(1+a^{2}\right)\left(1+b^{2}\right)\left(1+c^{2}\right)$$

Equality in (54) holds if and only if \(a=b=c=1\). -/
theorem inequalities_599601 {a b c : ℝ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (habc : a * b * c = 1) :
    (b + c) * (c + a) * (a + b) * (a + b + c) ≥
    3 * (1 + a ^ 2) * (1 + b ^ 2) * (1 + c ^ 2) ∧
    ((b + c) * (c + a) * (a + b) * (a + b + c) =
     3 * (1 + a ^ 2) * (1 + b ^ 2) * (1 + c ^ 2) ↔ a = 1 ∧ b = 1 ∧ c = 1) := by

informal_statement:
Determine all integers $m$ for which there exists a polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ satisfying the following conditions:
1. For all $x \in \mathbb{Z}$, $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod{m}$ or $f(x) \equiv 1 \pmod{m}$.
2. There exist integers $u, v \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $f(u) \equiv 0 \pmod{m}$ and $f(v) \equiv 1 \pmod{m}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine all integers $m$ for which there exists a polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ satisfying the following conditions:
1. For all $x \in \mathbb{Z}$, $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod{m}$ or $f(x) \equiv 1 \pmod{m}$.
2. There exist integers $u, v \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $f(u) \equiv 0 \pmod{m}$ and $f(v) \equiv 1 \pmod{m}$. -/
theorem number_theory_4951 (m : ℕ) :
    ∃ f : Polynomial ℤ, (∀ x : ℤ, f.eval x ≡ 0 [ZMOD m] ∨ f.eval x ≡ 1 [ZMOD m]) ∧
      ∃ u v : ℤ, f.eval u ≡ 0 [ZMOD m] ∧ f.eval v ≡ 1 [ZMOD m] ↔
    ∃ p k : ℕ, Nat.Prime p ∧ k ≥ 1 ∧ m = p ^ k := by

soln_description:
Solution. From the condition of the problem, it follows that

$$
\overline{a a b b}=1100 a+11 b=11(100 a+b)=k^{2}, \quad k \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

which means that $100 a+b=11 l^{2}, l \in \mathbb{Z}$, where $a, b \in\{1,2, \ldots, 9\}$. By direct verification, the only possibility is $l=8, a=7, b=4$.

Indeed, $88^{2}=7744$.
informal_statement: 1. Determine a four-digit number that is a square of a natural number and where the first two digits and the last two digits are equal.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Determine a four-digit number that is a square of a natural number and where the first two digits and the last two digits are equal. -/
theorem number_theory_247259 {n : ℕ} (hn : n^2 = 7744) :
    (n / 100) % 100 = n % 100 := by

informal_statement: Let $n$ be a positive integer. Prove that \[\frac{1}{3}+\cdots+\frac{1}{2n+1}\] is not an integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $n$ be a positive integer. Prove that \[\frac{1}{3}+\cdots+\frac{1}{2n+1}\] is not an integer. -/
theorem number_theory_68672 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) :
    ¬ ∃ k : ℤ, ∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, (1 / (2 * i + 3)) = k := by

soln_description:
$p=2(a-2 b-4)^{2}+9(b-2)^{2}+1976 \geq 1976$. The equality $p=1976$ is possible if $b=2, a-2 b-4=0$, that is, when $a=8, b=2$.

## Answer

When $a=8, b=2 ; 1976$.
informal_statement: For what values of $a$ and $b$ does the expression $p=2 a^{2}-8 a b+17 b^{2}-16 a-4 b+2044$ take its minimum value? What is this value?
informal_proof:
Let the function `p` be defined for all real numbers `a` and `b` as `p(a, b) = 2a² - 8ab + 17b² - 16a - 4b + 2044`. We want to prove two things: first, that the minimum value of `p(a, b)` is 1976, and second, that this minimum is achieved for `a = 8` and `b = 2`.

The proof is in two parts.

**Part 1: 1976 is the minimum value.**

To show that 1976 is the minimum value (i.e., the least element of the set of values taken by `p`), we must show two conditions:
1.  1976 is a value that `p` can take (membership in the range).
2.  For any value `x` in the range of `p`, `1976 ≤ x` (it is a lower bound).

For the first condition, we demonstrate that there exist `a` and `b` such that `p(a, b) = 1976`. Let `a = 8` and `b = 2`. Substituting these values into the expression for `p` yields:
`p(8, 2) = 2(8)² - 8(8)(2) + 17(2)² - 16(8) - 4(2) + 2044`
`= 2(64) - 128 + 17(4) - 128 - 8 + 2044`
`= 128 - 128 + 68 - 128 - 8 + 2044`
`= 1976`
Thus, 1976 is in the range of `p`.

For the second condition, we show that `p(a, b) ≥ 1976` for all `a, b ∈ ℝ`. We do this by rewriting the expression for `p(a, b)` by completing the square. The expression can be shown to be algebraically equivalent to:
`p(a, b) = 2(a - 2b - 4)² + 9(b - 2)² + 1976`
This identity can be verified by expanding the squared terms on the right-hand side.

Since `a` and `b` are real numbers, the terms `(a - 2b - 4)` and `(b - 2)` are also real numbers. The square of any real number is non-negative, so we have:
-   `(a - 2b - 4)² ≥ 0`
-   `(b - 2)² ≥ 0`

Multiplying by positive constants preserves this property, so `2(a - 2b - 4)² ≥ 0` and `9(b - 2)² ≥ 0`. The sum of these two non-negative terms must also be non-negative:
`2(a - 2b - 4)² + 9(b - 2)² ≥ 0`

From our algebraic identity, it follows that:
`p(a, b) = (a non-negative value) + 1976`
Therefore, `p(a, b) ≥ 1976` for all `a, b ∈ ℝ`. This establishes that 1976 is a lower bound for the values of `p`.

Since 1976 is in the range of `p` and is also a lower bound for all values in the range, it is the minimum value.

**Part 2: The minimum is achieved at a = 8, b = 2.**

We need to show that there exist `a` and `b` such that `p(a, b) = 1976`, `a = 8`, and `b = 2`. We choose `a = 8` and `b = 2`. As calculated in Part 1, `p(8, 2) = 1976`. The conditions on `a` and `b` are met by our choice.

Thus, we have shown both that 1976 is the minimum value and that this minimum is attained at `a=8, b=2`. This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- For what values of $a$ and $b$ does the expression $p=2 a^{2}-8 a b+17 b^{2}-16 a-4 b+2044$ take its minimum value? What is this value? -/
theorem algebra_195805 (p : ℝ → ℝ → ℝ)
    (h₀ : ∀ a b, p a b = 2 * a ^ 2 - 8 * a * b + 17 * b ^ 2 - 16 * a - 4 * b + 2044) :
    IsLeast {x | ∃ a b, x = p a b} 1976 ∧ ∃ a b, p a b = 1976 ∧ a = 8 ∧ b = 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_195805 (p : ℝ → ℝ → ℝ)
    (h₀ : ∀ a b, p a b = 2 * a ^ 2 - 8 * a * b + 17 * b ^ 2 - 16 * a - 4 * b + 2044) :
    IsLeast {x | ∃ a b, x = p a b} 1976 ∧ ∃ a b, p a b = 1976 ∧ a = 8 ∧ b = 2 := by

  constructor
  · -- Show 1976 is the least value
    constructor
    · -- Show 1976 is in the range
      use 8, 2
      norm_num [h₀]
    · -- Show no smaller value exists
      intro x hx
      rcases hx with ⟨a, b, h_eq⟩
      have h1 : p a b = 2 * (a - 2 * b - 4) ^ 2 + 9 * (b - 2) ^ 2 + 1976 := by
        rw [h₀ a b]
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - 2 * b - 4), sq_nonneg (b - 2)]
      have h2 : x = 2 * (a - 2 * b - 4) ^ 2 + 9 * (b - 2) ^ 2 + 1976 := by
        rw [h_eq]
        linarith [h1]
      have h3 : 2 * (a - 2 * b - 4) ^ 2 + 9 * (b - 2) ^ 2 ≥ 0 := by
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - 2 * b - 4), sq_nonneg (b - 2)]
      linarith [h2, h3]

  · -- Show there exist a, b such that p a b = 1976 and a = 8, b = 2
    use 8, 2
    norm_num [h₀]

soln_description:
Given $a-b=m q$, where $q$ is an integer, we have
$$a^{n}=(b+m q)^{n}=b^{n}+\cdots+(m q)^{n}=b^{n}+m q_{1}$$

where $q_{1}$ is an integer. Therefore, $a^{n}-b^{n}=m q_{1}$, which means
$$a^{n} \equiv b^{n}(\bmod m)$$
informal_statement:
Lemma 3 If $a, b$ are any two integers, and $m, n$ are two positive integers, then when $a \equiv b(\bmod m)$, we have
$$a^{n} \equiv b^{n}(\bmod m)$$
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be integers, and let $m$ and $n$ be positive natural numbers. We are given that $a \equiv b \pmod{m}$ and we want to prove that $a^n \equiv b^n \pmod{m}$.

The proof relies on a standard property of modular arithmetic: congruence is preserved under exponentiation. This property is formalized in the Lean `Mathlib` library as the lemma `Int.ModEq.pow`. The proof simply applies this lemma to our hypothesis.

To provide a complete, self-contained argument, we will prove this property from first principles.

The initial assumption $a \equiv b \pmod{m}$ means that $m$ divides the difference $a - b$. By definition, this implies there exists an integer $k$ such that:
$$a - b = k \cdot m$$

Now, consider the expression $a^n - b^n$. We can use the well-known algebraic identity for the difference of powers:
$$a^n - b^n = (a - b) \left( \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} a^{n-1-i} b^i \right)$$
$$a^n - b^n = (a - b) (a^{n-1} + a^{n-2}b + \dots + ab^{n-2} + b^{n-1})$$

Substitute the expression for $(a - b)$ from our initial assumption:
$$a^n - b^n = (k \cdot m) \left( \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} a^{n-1-i} b^i \right)$$

Since $a$ and $b$ are integers, the sum $\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} a^{n-1-i} b^i$ is also an integer. Let's call this sum $S$. Then the equation becomes:
$$a^n - b^n = m \cdot (k \cdot S)$$
Since $k$ and $S$ are integers, their product $k \cdot S$ is also an integer. This shows that $a^n - b^n$ is a multiple of $m$, which means $m$ divides $a^n - b^n$.

By the definition of modular congruence, this is equivalent to:
$$a^n \equiv b^n \pmod{m}$$
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Lemma 3 If $a, b$ are any two integers, and $m, n$ are two positive integers, then when $a \equiv b(\bmod m)$, we have
$$a^{n} \equiv b^{n}(\bmod m)$$ -/
theorem number_theory_7073 (a b : ℤ) (m n : ℕ) (_ : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n)
    (h : a ≡ b [ZMOD m]) : a ^ n ≡ b ^ n [ZMOD m] := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_7073 (a b : ℤ) (m n : ℕ) (_ : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n)
    (h : a ≡ b [ZMOD m]) : a ^ n ≡ b ^ n [ZMOD m] := by 
  exact Int.ModEq.pow n h

soln_description:
We will try to construct a solution with $a=1$. Necessarily, $b^{2} \pm 4 c$ must be the square of an integer. Therefore, there must exist integers $u$ and $v$ such that $u^{2}=b^{2}-4 c$ and $v^{2}=b^{2}+4 c$. We then have $u^{2}+v^{2}=2 b^{2}$.

This equation has an infinite number of solutions, for example $u=1, v=7$ and $b=5$. This gives us the equations $x^{2} \pm 5 x \pm 6=0$.

Proposition 118 (Sum and Product of the Roots). Consider an equation of the form $x^{2}-S x+P=0$ where $S$ and $P$ are two real numbers. Suppose there are two distinct solutions. Then $S$ is the sum, and $P$ is the product of the two solutions.

Indeed, it suffices to calculate $x_{1}+x_{2}$ and $x_{1} x_{2}$ where $x_{1}=\frac{S+\sqrt{S^{2}-4 P}}{2}$ and $x_{2}=\frac{S-\sqrt{S^{2}-4 P}}{2}$. The following exercise has not been covered in class.
informal_statement: (Moscow 2003, problem C1) Do there exist strictly positive integers $a, b, c$ such that the four equations $a x^{2} \pm b x \pm c=0$ each have two non-zero integer roots?
informal_proof:
We will prove the statement by construction. Let us choose the integers `a = 1`, `b = 5`, and `c = 6`. We will show that these values satisfy all the required conditions.

First, we must verify that `a`, `b`, and `c` are strictly positive integers.
- `a = 1 > 0`
- `b = 5 > 0`
- `c = 6 > 0`
This condition is satisfied.

Next, we must show that for these values of `a`, `b`, and `c`, each of the four equations `a * x^2 ± b * x ± c = 0` has two non-zero integer roots.

**Case 1: `a * x^2 + b * x + c = 0`**
The equation is `x^2 + 5x + 6 = 0`. We propose the integer roots `x₁ = -2` and `x₂ = -3`.
- Both roots are non-zero: `-2 ≠ 0` and `-3 ≠ 0`.
- We verify that they are roots by substitution:
  - For `x₁ = -2`: `1 * (-2)^2 + 5 * (-2) + 6 = 1 * 4 - 10 + 6 = 4 - 10 + 6 = 0`.
  - For `x₂ = -3`: `1 * (-3)^2 + 5 * (-3) + 6 = 1 * 9 - 15 + 6 = 9 - 15 + 6 = 0`.
Thus, this equation has two non-zero integer roots.

**Case 2: `a * x^2 - b * x + c = 0`**
The equation is `x^2 - 5x + 6 = 0`. We propose the integer roots `x₃ = 2` and `x₄ = 3`.
- Both roots are non-zero: `2 ≠ 0` and `3 ≠ 0`.
- We verify that they are roots by substitution:
  - For `x₃ = 2`: `1 * 2^2 - 5 * 2 + 6 = 1 * 4 - 10 + 6 = 4 - 10 + 6 = 0`.
  - For `x₄ = 3`: `1 * 3^2 - 5 * 3 + 6 = 1 * 9 - 15 + 6 = 9 - 15 + 6 = 0`.
Thus, this equation has two non-zero integer roots.

**Case 3: `a * x^2 + b * x - c = 0`**
The equation is `x^2 + 5x - 6 = 0`. We propose the integer roots `x₅ = 1` and `x₆ = -6`.
- Both roots are non-zero: `1 ≠ 0` and `-6 ≠ 0`.
- We verify that they are roots by substitution:
  - For `x₅ = 1`: `1 * 1^2 + 5 * 1 - 6 = 1 + 5 - 6 = 0`.
  - For `x₆ = -6`: `1 * (-6)^2 + 5 * (-6) - 6 = 1 * 36 - 30 - 6 = 36 - 30 - 6 = 0`.
Thus, this equation has two non-zero integer roots.

**Case 4: `a * x^2 - b * x - c = 0`**
The equation is `x^2 - 5x - 6 = 0`. We propose the integer roots `x₇ = 6` and `x₈ = -1`.
- Both roots are non-zero: `6 ≠ 0` and `-1 ≠ 0`.
- We verify that they are roots by substitution:
  - For `x₇ = 6`: `1 * 6^2 - 5 * 6 - 6 = 1 * 36 - 30 - 6 = 36 - 30 - 6 = 0`.
  - For `x₈ = -1`: `1 * (-1)^2 - 5 * (-1) - 6 = 1 * 1 + 5 - 6 = 1 + 5 - 6 = 0`.
Thus, this equation has two non-zero integer roots.

Since we have found strictly positive integers `a=1`, `b=5`, `c=6` for which all four equations have two distinct, non-zero integer roots, the existence is proven.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (Moscow 2003, problem C1) Do there exist strictly positive integers $a, b, c$ such that the four equations $a x^{2} \pm b x \pm c=0$ each have two non-zero integer roots? -/
theorem algebra_142316 :
    ∃ a b c : ℤ, a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ c > 0 ∧
      (∃ x1 x2 : ℤ, x1 ≠ 0 ∧ x2 ≠ 0 ∧ a * x1^2 + b * x1 + c = 0 ∧ a * x2^2 + b * x2 + c = 0) ∧
      (∃ x3 x4 : ℤ, x3 ≠ 0 ∧ x4 ≠ 0 ∧ a * x3^2 - b * x3 + c = 0 ∧ a * x4^2 - b * x4 + c = 0) ∧
      (∃ x5 x6 : ℤ, x5 ≠ 0 ∧ x6 ≠ 0 ∧ a * x5^2 + b * x5 - c = 0 ∧ a * x6^2 + b * x6 - c = 0) ∧
      (∃ x7 x8 : ℤ, x7 ≠ 0 ∧ x8 ≠ 0 ∧ a * x7^2 - b * x7 - c = 0 ∧ a * x8^2 - b * x8 - c = 0) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_142316 :
    ∃ a b c : ℤ, a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ c > 0 ∧
      (∃ x1 x2 : ℤ, x1 ≠ 0 ∧ x2 ≠ 0 ∧ a * x1^2 + b * x1 + c = 0 ∧ a * x2^2 + b * x2 + c = 0) ∧
      (∃ x3 x4 : ℤ, x3 ≠ 0 ∧ x4 ≠ 0 ∧ a * x3^2 - b * x3 + c = 0 ∧ a * x4^2 - b * x4 + c = 0) ∧
      (∃ x5 x6 : ℤ, x5 ≠ 0 ∧ x6 ≠ 0 ∧ a * x5^2 + b * x5 - c = 0 ∧ a * x6^2 + b * x6 - c = 0) ∧
      (∃ x7 x8 : ℤ, x7 ≠ 0 ∧ x8 ≠ 0 ∧ a * x7^2 - b * x7 - c = 0 ∧ a * x8^2 - b * x8 - c = 0) := by
  use 1
  use 5
  use 6
  constructor
  · norm_num
  constructor
  · norm_num
  constructor
  · norm_num
  constructor
  · -- roots for x^2 +5x +6 =0
    use -2, -3
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · -- verify -2 is a root
      norm_num
    · -- verify -3 is a root
      norm_num
  constructor
  · -- roots for x^2 -5x +6 =0
    use 2, 3
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · -- verify 2 is a root
      norm_num
    · -- verify 3 is a root
      norm_num
  constructor
  · -- roots for x^2 +5x -6 =0
    use 1, -6
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · -- verify 1 is a root
      norm_num
    · -- verify -6 is a root
      norm_num
  · -- roots for x^2 -5x -6 =0
    use 6, -1
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · -- verify 6 is a root
      norm_num
    · -- verify -1 is a root
      norm_num

soln_description:
If all ten digits are to occur exactly once, the number must be ten digits long and have a cross sum of 45. A number is divisible by 11 if and only if the difference between the sum $x$ of the digits in even positions and the sum $y$ of the digits in odd positions is zero or a multiple of 11. Thus, we have the system of equations

$$
x+y=45 \quad ; \quad x-y=11 k
$$

with $k=0 ; \pm 1 ; \pm 2, \ldots$ to be solved in positive integers. This results in

$$
x=\frac{45+11 k}{2} \quad ; \quad y=\frac{45-11 k}{2}
$$

From this, it follows: 1. $k$ is odd; 2. $|k|<5$ (otherwise either $x$ or $y$ would be negative). Therefore, only the values $k= \pm 1$ and $k= \pm 3$ are possible.

I. $k= \pm 1$ yields $x=28, y=17$ or $x=17, y=28$.

II. $k= \pm 3$ yields $x=39, y=6$ or $x=6, y=39$.

Case II does not provide a valid solution, as five different digits always yield a sum greater than 6.

Therefore, (Case I) the ten digits must be divided into two groups of five such that one group has a sum of 28 and the other a sum of 17. The largest number sought will then result if the digits in each group are arranged in descending order (from left to right) and as many odd digits as possible are used in the even-positioned group, and as many even digits as possible are used in the odd-positioned group (where the positions are counted from the units place):

even-positioned group: 97543

odd-positioned group: 86210

sought number: 9876524130
informal_statement:
## Task 25/66

What is the largest multiple of 11 in which none of the digits occurs more than once?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 25/66

What is the largest multiple of 11 in which none of the digits occurs more than once? -/
theorem number_theory_148835 :
    IsGreatest {n | 11 ∣ n ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).length = 10 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).toFinset.card = 10} 9876524130 := by

soln_description:
8. 2 .

Let $x=\omega\left(\omega=-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \mathrm{i}\right)$. Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x^{2}+x+2=1 \\
\Rightarrow \sum_{k=0}^{1344}\left(a_{3 k}+a_{3 k+1} \omega+a_{3 k+2} \omega^{2}\right)=1
\end{array}
$$

Taking the conjugate of the above equation, we get
$$
\sum_{k=0}^{1344}\left(a_{3 k}+a_{3 k+1} \omega^{2}+a_{3 k+2} \omega\right)=1 \text {. }
$$

Adding the two equations, we get
$$
\sum_{k=0}^{1344}\left(2 a_{3 k}-a_{3 k+1}-a_{3 k+2}\right)=2 \text {. }
$$
informal_statement: 8. If $f(x)=\sum_{k=0}^{4034} a_{k} x^{k}$ is the expansion of $\left(x^{2}+x+2\right)^{2017}$, then $\sum_{k=0}^{1344}\left(2 a_{3 k}-a_{3 k+1}-a_{3 k+2}\right)=$ $\qquad$

/- 8. If $f(x)=\sum_{k=0}^{4034} a_{k} x^{k}$ is the expansion of $\left(x^{2}+x+2\right)^{2017}$, then $\sum_{k=0}^{1344}\left(2 a_{3 k}-a_{3 k+1}-a_{3 k+2}\right)=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_299869 (f : Polynomial ℝ) (hf : f = (X^2 + X + 2)^2017) :
    ∑ k in Finset.range 1345, (2 * f.coeff (3 * k) - f.coeff (3 * k + 1) - f.coeff (3 * k + 2)) = 2 := by

soln_description:
1. **Define the assertion**: Let \( P(x, y) \) be the assertion \( f(x + y) + f(x - y) = 2f(x) + 2f(y) \).

2. **Evaluate \( P(0, 0) \)**:
   \[
   P(0, 0) \implies f(0 + 0) + f(0 - 0) = 2f(0) + 2f(0) \implies 2f(0) = 4f(0) \implies f(0) = 0
   \]

3. **Evaluate \( P(x, 0) \)**:
   \[
   P(x, 0) \implies f(x + 0) + f(x - 0) = 2f(x) + 2f(0) \implies f(x) + f(x) = 2f(x) + 0 \implies 2f(x) = 2f(x)
   \]
   This equation is always true and does not provide new information.

4. **Evaluate \( P(x, x) \)**:
   \[
   P(x, x) \implies f(x + x) + f(x - x) = 2f(x) + 2f(x) \implies f(2x) + f(0) = 4f(x) \implies f(2x) = 4f(x)
   \]

5. **Induction on \( n \)**:
   - For \( n = 1 \), we have \( f(x) = f(x) \), which is trivially true.
   - Assume \( f(nx) = n^2 f(x) \) holds for some \( n \in \mathbb{N} \).
   - Evaluate \( P(nx, x) \):
     \[
     P(nx, x) \implies f(nx + x) + f(nx - x) = 2f(nx) + 2f(x) \implies f((n+1)x) + f((n-1)x) = 2f(nx) + 2f(x)
     \]
     By the induction hypothesis:
     \[
     f((n+1)x) + f((n-1)x) = 2n^2 f(x) + 2f(x)
     \]
     We also know from the induction hypothesis:
     \[
     f((n-1)x) = (n-1)^2 f(x)
     \]
     Therefore:
     \[
     f((n+1)x) + (n-1)^2 f(x) = 2n^2 f(x) + 2f(x)
     \]
     Simplifying:
     \[
     f((n+1)x) + (n^2 - 2n + 1) f(x) = 2n^2 f(x) + 2f(x)
     \]
     \[
     f((n+1)x) = 2n^2 f(x) + 2f(x) - (n^2 - 2n + 1) f(x)
     \]
     \[
     f((n+1)x) = (2n^2 + 2 - n^2 + 2n - 1) f(x)
     \]
     \[
     f((n+1)x) = (n^2 + 2n + 1) f(x)
     \]
     \[
     f((n+1)x) = (n+1)^2 f(x)
     \]
     Thus, by induction, \( f(nx) = n^2 f(x) \) holds for all \( n \in \mathbb{N} \).

6. **Extend to negative integers**:
   - For \( n = -1 \):
     \[
     P(x, -x) \implies f(x - x) + f(x + x) = 2f(x) + 2f(-x) \implies f(0) + f(2x) = 2f(x) + 2f(-x) \implies 4f(x) = 2f(x) + 2f(-x)
     \]
     \[
     2f(x) = 2f(-x) \implies f(x) = f(-x)
     \]
     Thus, \( f \) is an even function.

7. **Generalize to rational numbers**:
   - For any rational \( x = \frac{p}{q} \) with \( p, q \in \mathbb{Z} \):
     \[
     f\left(\frac{p}{q}\right) = \left(\frac{p}{q}\right)^2 f(1) = \frac{p^2}{q^2} f(1)
     \]
     Let \( f(1) = a \), where \( a \in \mathbb{Q} \). Then:
     \[
     f\left(\frac{p}{q}\right) = a \left(\frac{p}{q}\right)^2
     \]
     Therefore, the general solution is:
     \[
     f(x) = ax^2 \quad \forall x \in \mathbb{Q}
     \]

Conclusion:
\[
\boxed{f(x) = ax^2 \quad \forall x \in \mathbb{Q}}
\]
informal_statement: Determine all functions $ f$ defined in the set of rational numbers and taking their values in the same set such that the equation $ f(x + y) + f(x - y) = 2f(x) + 2f(y)$ holds for all rational numbers $x$ and $y$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine all functions $ f$ defined in the set of rational numbers and taking their values in the same set such that the equation $ f(x + y) + f(x - y) = 2f(x) + 2f(y)$ holds for all rational numbers $x$ and $y$. -/
theorem algebra_58262 (f : ℚ → ℚ) :
    (∀ x y, f (x + y) + f (x - y) = 2 * f x + 2 * f y) ↔
    ∃ c, ∀ x, f x = c * x ^ 2 := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let's redraw the cycle in the $p v$ diagram. There, the line first goes down, then to the left, and then closes along some curve. Since the pressure at all points does not exceed $n P_{0}$, and the volume $V_{0}=m / \rho_{0}$, where $m$ is the mass of the gas, the maximum temperature is $T_{1}=n P_{0} V_{0} / R$. Similarly, the minimum temperature of the gas is $T_{3}=P_{0} V_{0} /(n R)$. The highest efficiency for such a range of temperatures is $1-T_{2} / T_{1}$, therefore, the efficiency of the considered cycle is $(1 / \alpha) \cdot\left(1-1 / n^{2}\right)$.

Answer. $1 / 9$
informal_statement: 4.2.1 An ideal gas is used as the working substance of a cyclic heat engine. The cycle consists of three stages: isochoric pressure reduction from $3 P_{0}$ to $P_{0}$, isobaric density increase from $\rho_{0}$ to $3 \rho_{0}$, and return to the initial state, where the process in the $P / P_{0}, \rho / \rho_{0}$ axes is represented by a quarter circle centered at the point $(1,1)$. Determine the efficiency of this cycle, knowing that it is 8 times less than the maximum possible efficiency for the same minimum and maximum gas temperatures as in this cycle.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 4.2.1 An ideal gas is used as the working substance of a cyclic heat engine. The cycle consists of three stages: isochoric pressure reduction from $3 P_{0}$ to $P_{0}$, isobaric density increase from $\rho_{0}$ to $3 \rho_{0}$, and return to the initial state, where the process in the $P / P_{0}, \rho / \rho_{0}$ axes is represented by a quarter circle centered at the point $(1,1)$. Determine the efficiency of this cycle, knowing that it is 8 times less than the maximum possible efficiency for the same minimum and maximum gas temperatures as in this cycle. -/
theorem other_279741 {P0 : ℝ} (hP0 : P0 > 0) :
    (1 / 9) = (4 * π * P0 ^ 2) / (8 * π * (P0 / 3) ^ 2) := by

informal_statement: If I have four boxes arranged in a $2$ x $2$ grid, in how many distinct ways can I place the digits $1$, $2$, and $3$ in the boxes such that each box contains at most one digit?  (I only have one of each digit, so one box will remain blank.)
informal_proof:
The goal is to prove the equality `(Nat.factorial 4) / (Nat.factorial 1) = 24`.

We proceed by direct computation of the left-hand side of the equation.

First, we evaluate the numerator, `Nat.factorial 4` (also written as $4!$). By the definition of the factorial function, we have:
$4! = 4 \times 3 \times 2 \times 1 = 24$.

Next, we evaluate the denominator, `Nat.factorial 1` (or $1!$):
$1! = 1$.

Substituting these values back into the expression, we get:
$$ \frac{\text{Nat.factorial } 4}{\text{Nat.factorial } 1} = \frac{24}{1} $$

Finally, performing the division yields:
$$ \frac{24}{1} = 24 $$

This shows that the left-hand side of the equation is equal to $24$, which matches the right-hand side. Thus, the equality `(Nat.factorial 4) / (Nat.factorial 1) = 24` is true.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If I have four boxes arranged in a $2$ x $2$ grid, in how many distinct ways can I place the digits $1$, $2$, and $3$ in the boxes such that each box contains at most one digit?  (I only have one of each digit, so one box will remain blank.) -/
theorem algebra_14620 : (Nat.factorial 4) / (Nat.factorial 1) = 24 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_14620 : (Nat.factorial 4) / (Nat.factorial 1) = 24 := by
  norm_num [Nat.factorial]

soln_description:
4. Notice that, the sum of the first three terms in the original expression is
$$
\left(1+\frac{1}{x}\right)\left(1+\frac{2}{y}\right),
$$

adding the fourth term gives
$$
\left(1+\frac{1}{x}\right)\left(1+\frac{2}{y}\right)\left(1+\frac{3}{z}\right),
$$

and adding the fifth term, the original expression is equivalent to
$$
\left(1+\frac{1}{x}\right)\left(1+\frac{2}{y}\right)\left(1+\frac{3}{z}\right)\left(1+\frac{4}{w}\right)=0 .
$$

Thus, $1+\frac{1}{x}=0$ or $1+\frac{2}{y}=0$ or $1+\frac{3}{z}=0$ or $1+\frac{4}{w}=0$, the solution set is the set of $(x, y, z, w)$.
Since $x y z w \neq 0$, we have $x=-1$ or $y=-2$ or $z=-3$ or $w=-4$.
informal_statement:
4. Find all non-zero tuples $(x, y, z, w)$ that satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
1+\frac{1}{x}+\frac{2(x+1)}{x y}+\frac{3(x+1)(y+2)}{x y z}+ \\
\frac{4(x+1)(y+2)(z+3)}{x y z w}=0
\end{array}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Find all non-zero tuples $(x, y, z, w)$ that satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
1+\frac{1}{x}+\frac{2(x+1)}{x y}+\frac{3(x+1)(y+2)}{x y z}+ \\
\frac{4(x+1)(y+2)(z+3)}{x y z w}=0
\end{array}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_199565 {x y z w : ℝ} (hx : x ≠ 0) (hy : y ≠ 0) (hz : z ≠ 0) (hw : w ≠ 0)
    (h : 1 + 1 / x + 2 * (x + 1) / (x * y) + 3 * (x + 1) * (y + 2) / (x * y * z) +
      4 * (x + 1) * (y + 2) * (z + 3) / (x * y * z * w) = 0) :
    (x, y, z, w) = (-1, -2, -3, -4) := by

soln_description:
8.1.

Let $f(t)=t^{3}+\sin t$. Then $f(t)$ is monotonically increasing on $\left[-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$.

From the original system of equations, we get $f(x)=f(-2 y)=2 a$, and since $x$ and $-2 y \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$, it follows that $x=-2 y$, hence $x+2 y=0$. Therefore, $\cos (x+2 y)=1$.
informal_statement:
8. Given $x, y \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{\pi}{4}\right], a \in \mathbf{R}$, and
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x^{3}+\sin x-2 a=0, \\
4 y^{3}+\frac{1}{2} \sin 2 y+a=0 .
\end{array}\right.
$$

then the value of $\cos (x+2 y)$ is
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8. Given $x, y \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{\pi}{4}\right], a \in \mathbf{R}$, and
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x^{3}+\sin x-2 a=0, \\
4 y^{3}+\frac{1}{2} \sin 2 y+a=0 .
\end{array}\right.
$$

then the value of $\cos (x+2 y)$ is -/
theorem algebra_309381 (x y : ℝ) (a : ℝ) (hx : x ∈ Set.Icc (-Real.pi / 4) (Real.pi / 4)) (hy : y ∈ Set.Icc (-Real.pi / 4) (Real.pi / 4))
    (h1 : x^3 + Real.sin x - 2 * a = 0) (h2 : 4 * y^3 + (1 / 2) * Real.sin (2 * y) + a = 0) :
    Real.cos (x + 2 * y) = 1 := by

soln_description:
8. $(52,29)$ or $(53,15)$.

Notice that, for positive integers $a>b$, we have $(a+b)^{2}>a^{2}+b^{2} \geqslant \frac{(a+b)^{2}}{2}$.
Thus, $\frac{a+b}{2} \leqslant q2020$
$\Rightarrow q=44$ or $q=43$.
Upon inspection, when $q=43$, $2 r=2020-43^{2}=$
171 is odd, which is a contradiction; when $q=44$, $r=42$.
Therefore, $a^{2}+b^{2}=44 a+44 b+42$
$\Rightarrow(a-22)^{2}+(b-22)^{2}=1010$.
By enumeration, we get $31^{2}+7^{2}=1010$.
Also, $a+b>42$, hence, there are two solutions that satisfy the requirements: $(a, b)=(53,29)$ or $(53,15)$.
informal_statement: 8. Given that $a>b$ are positive integers. Let the quotient when $a^{2}+b^{2}$ is divided by $a+b$ be $q$, and the remainder be $r$. If $q^{2}+2 r=2020$, then the ordered pair of real numbers $(a, b)=$ $\qquad$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8. Given that $a>b$ are positive integers. Let the quotient when $a^{2}+b^{2}$ is divided by $a+b$ be $q$, and the remainder be $r$. If $q^{2}+2 r=2020$, then the ordered pair of real numbers $(a, b)=$ $\qquad$ . -/
theorem number_theory_172073 (a b q r : ℕ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (h : a > b)
    (hq : (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / (a + b) = q) (hr : (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) % (a + b) = r)
    (hqr : q ^ 2 + 2 * r = 2020) :
    (a = 52 ∧ b = 29) ∨ (a = 53 ∧ b = 15) := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Domain of definition: $\sin t \neq 0$.

Write the equation in the form

$\frac{4 \cos ^{2} t-1}{\sin t}=\frac{\cos t\left(1+2\left(2 \cos ^{2} t-1\right)\right)}{\sin t} \Leftrightarrow$

$\Leftrightarrow 4 \cos ^{2} t-1=\cos t\left(4 \cos ^{2} t-1\right),\left(4 \cos ^{2} t-1\right)-\cos t\left(4 \cos ^{2} t-1\right)=0$, $\left(4 \cos ^{2} t-1\right)(1-\cos t)=0$.

## From this

1) $4 \cos ^{2} t-1=0, \cos ^{2} t=\frac{1}{4}, \cos t= \pm \frac{1}{2}, t_{1}= \pm \frac{\pi}{3}+\pi k=\frac{\pi}{3}(3 k \pm 1), k \in Z$;
2) $1-\cos t=0, \cos t=1$ - does not satisfy the domain of definition.

Answer: $x=\frac{\pi}{3}(3 k \pm 1), k \in Z$.

Translate the above text into English, keeping the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.

8.294. $\frac{4 \cos ^{2} t-1}{\sin t}=\operatorname{ctg} t(1+2 \cos 2 t)$. 

The above text in English, keeping the original text's line breaks and format, is:

8.294. $\frac{4 \cos ^{2} t-1}{\sin t}=\operatorname{ctg} t(1+2 \cos 2 t)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8.294. $\frac{4 \cos ^{2} t-1}{\sin t}=\operatorname{ctg} t(1+2 \cos 2 t)$. 

Translate the above text into English, keeping the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.

The above text in English, keeping the original text's line breaks and format, is:

soln_description:
Analyzing $|k|<2$, we associate $(a \pm b)^{2}=a^{2} \pm 2 a b+b^{2}$ and find that we can use trigonometric substitution to handle the parameter.
Proof: From $a^{2}+b^{2}-k a b=1$, we get: $\left(a-\frac{k}{2} b\right)^{2}+\left(1-\frac{k^{2}}{4}\right) b^{2}=1$
Let $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a-\frac{k}{2} b=\cos \alpha \\ \sqrt{1-\frac{k^{2}}{4}} b=\sin \alpha\end{array}\right.$, which means $\quad\left\{\begin{array}{l}b=\sqrt{\frac{4}{4-k^{2}}} \sin \alpha \\ a=\cos \alpha+\frac{k}{\sqrt{4-k^{2}}} \sin \alpha\end{array}\right.$
Similarly, let $\left\{\begin{array}{l}c=\sqrt{\frac{4}{4-k^{2}}} \sin \beta \\ d=\cos \beta+\frac{k}{\sqrt{4-k^{2}}} \sin \beta\end{array}\right.$
Therefore, $a c-b d=\frac{2}{\sqrt{4-k^{2}}} \cos \alpha \sin \beta+\frac{2 k}{4-k^{2}} \sin \alpha \sin \beta-\frac{2}{\sqrt{4-k^{2}}} \sin \alpha \cos \beta-\frac{2 k}{4-k^{2}} \sin \alpha \sin \beta$
$$
=\frac{2}{\sqrt{4-k^{2}}} \sin (\beta-\alpha) \text {, }
$$

Thus, $|a c-b d| \leqslant \frac{2}{\sqrt{4-k^{2}}}$.
Therefore, the inequality holds.
/Comment: Note that when substituting $c, d$, consider simplifying future calculations, and in the exploration process, first let $k=1$ to explore the approach.
informal_statement: Let $\ a, b, c, d, k \in \mathbf{R}$ and $|k|<2, a^{2}+b^{2}-k a b=1, c^{2}+d^{2}-k c d=1$. Prove: $|a c-b d| \leqslant \frac{2}{\sqrt{4-k^{2}}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $\ a, b, c, d, k \in \mathbf{R}$ and $|k|<2, a^{2}+b^{2}-k a b=1, c^{2}+d^{2}-k c d=1$. Prove: $|a c-b d| \leqslant \frac{2}{\sqrt{4-k^{2}}}$. -/
theorem inequalities_158529 (a b c d k : ℝ) (h₁ : |k| < 2)
    (h₂ : a^2 + b^2 - k * a * b = 1) (h₃ : c^2 + d^2 - k * c * d = 1) :
    |a * c - b * d| ≤ 2 / Real.sqrt (4 - k^2) := by

soln_description:
1. We start by assuming that the expression \(2abc - ab - bc - ca\) can be represented as \(bcx + cay + abz\) for some nonnegative integers \(x, y, z\). That is, we assume:
   \[
   2abc - ab - bc - ca = bcx + cay + abz
   \]

2. Consider the equation modulo \(a\). We have:
   \[
   2abc - ab - bc - ca \equiv bcx + cay + abz \pmod{a}
   \]
   Since \(a \mid ab\) and \(a \mid ca\), the left-hand side simplifies to:
   \[
   -bc \equiv bcx \pmod{a}
   \]
   Since \(\gcd(b, a) = 1\) and \(\gcd(c, a) = 1\), it follows that \(a \nmid bc\). Therefore, we must have:
   \[
   a \mid (x + 1)
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   x + 1 \geq a
   \]

3. Similarly, consider the equation modulo \(b\). We have:
   \[
   2abc - ab - bc - ca \equiv bcx + cay + abz \pmod{b}
   \]
   Since \(b \mid bc\) and \(b \mid ab\), the left-hand side simplifies to:
   \[
   -ca \equiv cay \pmod{b}
   \]
   Since \(\gcd(c, b) = 1\) and \(\gcd(a, b) = 1\), it follows that \(b \nmid ca\). Therefore, we must have:
   \[
   b \mid (y + 1)
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   y + 1 \geq b
   \]

4. Finally, consider the equation modulo \(c\). We have:
   \[
   2abc - ab - bc - ca \equiv bcx + cay + abz \pmod{c}
   \]
   Since \(c \mid ca\) and \(c \mid bc\), the left-hand side simplifies to:
   \[
   -ab \equiv abz \pmod{c}
   \]
   Since \(\gcd(a, c) = 1\) and \(\gcd(b, c) = 1\), it follows that \(c \nmid ab\). Therefore, we must have:
   \[
   c \mid (z + 1)
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   z + 1 \geq c
   \]

5. Combining these inequalities, we get:
   \[
   x + 1 \geq a, \quad y + 1 \geq b, \quad z + 1 \geq c
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   x \geq a - 1, \quad y \geq b - 1, \quad z \geq c - 1
   \]

6. Substituting these into the right-hand side of the original equation, we get:
   \[
   bcx + cay + abz \geq bc(a - 1) + ca(b - 1) + ab(c - 1)
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   bcx + cay + abz \geq abc - bc + abc - ca + abc - ab = 3abc - ab - bc - ca
   \]

7. However, this contradicts the original equation:
   \[
   2abc - ab - bc - ca = bcx + cay + abz
   \]
   Since \(3abc - ab - bc - ca > 2abc - ab - bc - ca\), we have a contradiction.

Therefore, the assumption that \(2abc - ab - bc - ca\) can be represented as \(bcx + cay + abz\) for nonnegative integers \(x, y, z\) is false.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $a, b, c$ be positive integers satisfying $\gcd (a, b) = \gcd (b, c) = \gcd (c, a) = 1$. Show that $2abc-ab-bc-ca$ cannot be represented as $bcx+cay +abz$ with nonnegative integers $x, y, z.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a, b, c$ be positive integers satisfying $\gcd (a, b) = \gcd (b, c) = \gcd (c, a) = 1$. Show that $2abc-ab-bc-ca$ cannot be represented as $bcx+cay +abz$ with nonnegative integers $x, y, z.$ -/
theorem number_theory_92564 (a b c : ℕ) (_ : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h1 : Nat.gcd a b = 1) (h2 : Nat.gcd b c = 1) (h3 : Nat.gcd c a = 1) :
    ¬∃ x y z : ℕ, 2*a*b*c - a*b - b*c - c*a = b*c*x + c*a*y + a*b*z := by

soln_description:
If $p>1$, by $(p, q)=1$, we can set $q=p s+r, 0<p$. Then, $\left(c^{p}-1\right) \mid\left(c^{q}-1\right)$, and
$$c^{g}-1=c^{\infty+r}-1=\left(c^{p}\right)^{s} \cdot c^{r}-1 \equiv 1^{s} \cdot c^{r}-1\left(\bmod c^{\rho}-1\right),$$

Therefore,
$$\left(c^{p}-1\right) \mid\left(c^{r}-1\right)$$

This cannot hold when $r<p$, so $p=1$, and (10) becomes
$$1+3^{m}=\left(1+3^{n}\right)^{q}$$

Noting that $q>p=1$, hence $q \geqslant 2$, at this time the right side of (11) $\equiv 0(\bmod 4)$, so
$$3^{m} \equiv-1(\bmod 4)$$

Thus, $m$ is odd, at this moment
$$1+3^{m}=(1+3)\left(1-3+3^{2}-\cdots+3^{m-1}\right)=4 \cdot A,$$

Here $A=1-3+3^{2}-\cdots+3^{m-1}$ is the sum of $m$ odd numbers, so $A$ is odd, thus $(4, A)=1$. This requires 4 and $A$ to both be $q$-th power numbers, from which we can deduce $q=2$, and then we can find
$$(m, n, p, q)=(1,0,1,2),$$

It is easy to verify that it meets the requirements.
informal_statement:
Example 8 Find all non-negative integer arrays $(m, n, p, q)$, such that $0<p<q,(p, q)=1$, and
$$\left(1+3^{m}\right)^{p}=\left(1+3^{n}\right)^{q} .$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 8 Find all non-negative integer arrays $(m, n, p, q)$, such that $0<p<q,(p, q)=1$, and
$$\left(1+3^{m}\right)^{p}=\left(1+3^{n}\right)^{q} .$$ -/
theorem number_theory_7474 (m n p q : ℕ) (h₀ : 0 < p) (h₁ : p < q)
    (h₂ : Nat.gcd p q = 1) (h₃ : (1 + 3 ^ m) ^ p = (1 + 3 ^ n) ^ q) :
    (m, n, p, q) = (1, 0, 1, 2) := by

soln_description:
16. E Square both sides to get $2018^{2}+2018^{2}+\ldots+2018^{2}=2018^{20}$.
Let $n$ be the number of occurrences of $2018^{2}$. Then we get $2018^{2} \times n=2018^{20}$.
So $n=\frac{2018^{20}}{2018^{2}}=2018^{18}$.
informal_statement:
16. In the calculation shown, how many times does the term $2018^{2}$ appear inside the square root to make the calculation correct?
$$
\sqrt{2018^{2}+2018^{2}+\ldots+2018^{2}}=2018^{10}
$$

A 5
B 8
C 18
D $2018^{8}$
E $2018^{18}$
informal_proof:
Let `n` be a natural number such that `n > 0`. We want to prove the equivalence:
$$ \sqrt{\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} 2018^2} = 2018^{10} \iff n = 2018^{18} $$
We prove this by showing both implications. All calculations involving non-integers are performed over the real numbers `ℝ`.

**Part 1: Forward Implication (⇒)**

Assume that $\sqrt{\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} 2018^2} = 2018^{10}$. Our goal is to show that $n = 2018^{18}$.

The sum inside the square root, $\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} 2018^2$, consists of adding the constant term $2018^2$ for `n` times (from `i=0` to `n-1`). Therefore, the sum is equal to $n \cdot 2018^2$.
Substituting this into our assumption, we get:
$$ \sqrt{n \cdot 2018^2} = 2018^{10} $$
To eliminate the square root, we square both sides of the equation:
$$ \left(\sqrt{n \cdot 2018^2}\right)^2 = (2018^{10})^2 $$
For the left-hand side, since $n > 0$, the term $n \cdot 2018^2$ is positive, so $(\sqrt{x})^2 = x$. Thus, the left side simplifies to $n \cdot 2018^2$.
For the right-hand side, using the exponent rule $(a^b)^c = a^{bc}$, we have $(2018^{10})^2 = 2018^{10 \cdot 2} = 2018^{20}$.
The equation now becomes:
$$ n \cdot 2018^2 = 2018^{20} $$
This equation holds over the real numbers, but since `n` is a natural number and all other terms are integers, we can treat this as an equation over the natural numbers. Dividing both sides by $2018^2$ (which is non-zero), we solve for `n`:
$$ n = \frac{2018^{20}}{2018^2} = 2018^{20-2} = 2018^{18} $$
This completes the proof of the forward implication.

**Part 2: Backward Implication (⇐)**

Assume that $n = 2018^{18}$. Our goal is to show that $\sqrt{\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} 2018^2} = 2018^{10}$.

We start with the left-hand side of the equation and substitute $n = 2018^{18}$:
$$ \sqrt{\sum_{i=0}^{2018^{18}-1} 2018^2} $$
As before, we simplify the sum:
$$ \sum_{i=0}^{2018^{18}-1} 2018^2 = 2018^{18} \cdot 2018^2 $$
Using the exponent rule $a^b \cdot a^c = a^{b+c}$, this simplifies to $2018^{18+2} = 2018^{20}$.
So, the expression becomes:
$$ \sqrt{2018^{20}} $$
To show that $\sqrt{2018^{20}} = 2018^{10}$, we can use the property that for a non-negative number $y$, $\sqrt{x} = y$ is equivalent to $x = y^2$. Here, $x = 2018^{20}$ and $y = 2018^{10}$.

First, we check that $y = 2018^{10}$ is non-negative, which is clearly true.
Second, we check if $x = y^2$. We need to verify if $2018^{20} = (2018^{10})^2$.
Using the power rule, $(2018^{10})^2 = 2018^{10 \cdot 2} = 2018^{20}$.
Since both conditions are met, the equality $\sqrt{2018^{20}} = 2018^{10}$ holds.

Thus, if $n = 2018^{18}$, the original equation is true. This completes the proof of the backward implication.

Since both directions of the implication have been proven, the equivalence holds.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 16. In the calculation shown, how many times does the term $2018^{2}$ appear inside the square root to make the calculation correct?
$$
\sqrt{2018^{2}+2018^{2}+\ldots+2018^{2}}=2018^{10}
$$

A 5
B 8
C 18
D $2018^{8}$
E $2018^{18}$ -/
theorem algebra_238859 (n : ℕ) (h : n > 0) :
    √(∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, (2018^2 : ℝ)) = 2018^10 ↔ n = 2018^18 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_238859 (n : ℕ) (h : n > 0) :
    √(∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, (2018^2 : ℝ)) = 2018^10 ↔ n = 2018^18 := by
  constructor
  · -- Assume $\sqrt{\sum_{i \in \text{range } n} 2018^2} = 2018^{10}$, prove $n = 2018^{18}$.
    intro h_eq
    have h_sum : ∑ i in Finset.range n, (2018^2 : ℝ) = (n : ℝ) * (2018 : ℝ)^2 := by
      simp [Finset.sum_const, Finset.card_range, mul_comm]
      <;> ring
    rw [h_sum] at h_eq
    have h_sq : (Real.sqrt ((n : ℝ) * (2018 : ℝ)^2)) ^ 2 = ((2018 ^ 10 : ℝ)) ^ 2 := by
      rw [h_eq]
    have h_left : (Real.sqrt ((n : ℝ) * (2018 : ℝ) ^ 2)) ^ 2 = (n : ℝ) * (2018 : ℝ) ^ 2 := by
      rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
      positivity
    have h_right : ((2018 ^ 10 : ℝ)) ^ 2 = (2018 : ℝ) ^ (20 : ℕ) := by
      norm_num
    rw [h_left, h_right] at h_sq
    have h_eq_nat : (n : ℝ) * (2018 : ℝ) ^ 2 = (2018 : ℝ) ^ (20 : ℕ) := by
      linarith
    have h_eq_nat' : n = 2018 ^ 18 := by
      have h1 : (n : ℝ) * (2018 : ℝ) ^ 2 = (2018 : ℝ) ^ (20 : ℕ) := by
        linarith
      have h2 : (n : ℝ) * (2018 : ℝ) ^ 2 = (2018 ^ 20 : ℝ) := by
        norm_num at h1 ⊢
        linarith
      have h2_nat : n * (2018 ^ 2) = (2018 ^ 20) := by
        exact_mod_cast h2
      nlinarith
    exact h_eq_nat'
  · -- Assume $n = 2018^{18}$, prove $\sqrt{\sum_{i \in \text{range } n} 2018^2} = 2018^{10}$.
    intro h_eq
    rw [show n = 2018 ^ 18 by linarith]
    have h_sum : ∑ i in Finset.range (2018 ^ 18), (2018^2 : ℝ) = (2018 ^ 18 : ℝ) * (2018 : ℝ)^2 := by
      simp [Finset.sum_const, Finset.card_range, mul_comm]
      <;> ring
    rw [h_sum]
    -- sqrt of ((2018 ^ 18) * (2018 ^ 2))
    -- becomes sqrt((2018 ^ (18 + 2))).
    -- which is sqrt((2018)^20) = (2018)^10.
    rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
    <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num

informal_statement: 23. [14] Let $f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ be a strictly increasing function such that $f(1)=1$ and $f(2 n) f(2 n+1)=$ $9 f(n)^{2}+3 f(n)$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Compute $f(137)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 23. [14] Let $f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ be a strictly increasing function such that $f(1)=1$ and $f(2 n) f(2 n+1)=$ $9 f(n)^{2}+3 f(n)$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Compute $f(137)$. -/
theorem algebra_177512 (f : ℕ → ℕ) (hf : StrictMono f)
    (h1 : f 1 = 1) (h2 : ∀ n, f (2 * n) * f (2 * n + 1) = 9 * (f n) ^ 2 + 3 * f n) :
    f 137 = 2215 := by

soln_description:
Solution. We will show that $f(x)=c$, where $c=\lim _{\substack{x \rightarrow 0 \\ x>0}} f(x)$.

Let $\lambda>0, x>0$ and $y=\lambda x$. Then from $f\left(\frac{x+y}{2}\right)=f(\sqrt{x y}) \Rightarrow f\left(\frac{1+\lambda}{2} \cdot x\right)=f(\sqrt{\lambda} \cdot x)$ $\Rightarrow f(x)=f\left(\frac{2 \sqrt{\lambda}}{1+\lambda} \cdot x\right), \forall x>0$.

If $a=\frac{2 \sqrt{\lambda}}{1+\lambda}$, then $0<a<1$ for all $\lambda>0$.

We deduce inductively that $f(x)=f\left(a^{n} x\right), \forall n \geq 1$. Since $a^{n} x \rightarrow 0$ as $n \rightarrow \infty \Rightarrow$ $\Rightarrow f(x)=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} f\left(a^{n} x\right)=c$.
informal_statement:
Problem 3. Let $f:[0,+\infty) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a function for which $\lim _{\substack{x \rightarrow 0 \\ x>0}} f(x)$ exists and is finite.

Show that if $f\left(\frac{x+y}{2}\right)=f(\sqrt{x y})$ for all $x, y>0$, then $f$ is a constant function.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Problem 3. Let $f:[0,+\infty) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a function for which $\lim _{\substack{x \rightarrow 0 \\ x>0}} f(x)$ exists and is finite.

Show that if $f\left(\frac{x+y}{2}\right)=f(\sqrt{x y})$ for all $x, y>0$, then $f$ is a constant function. -/
theorem algebra_120136 {f : ℝ → ℝ}
  (hf : ∃ L, Tendsto (λ x => f x) (𝓝[>] 0) (𝓝 L))
  (h : ∀ x y, 0 < x → 0 < y → f ((x + y) / 2) = f (Real.sqrt (x * y))) :
  ∃ c, ∀ x, 0 ≤ x → f x = c :=

soln_description:
First, we prove that for any $b \in \boldsymbol{N}$, we have
$$e+b=b+e.$$

When $b=e$, equation (10) clearly holds. Assume that equation (10) holds when $b=n$. When $b=n^{+}$, by equations (2), the assumption, and equation (1), we get
$$e+n^{+}=(e+n)^{+}=(n+e)^{+}=\left(n^{+}\right)^{+}=n^{+}+e,$$

which means equation (10) also holds. Therefore, by the principle of mathematical induction, equation (10) holds.
Equation (10) indicates that when $a=e$, equation (9) holds for any $b \in \boldsymbol{N}$. Assume that when $a=n$, equation (9) holds for any $b \in \boldsymbol{N}$. When $a=n^{+}$, for any $b \in \boldsymbol{N}$, using equations (1), (8), (10), (2), and the assumption, we get
$$\begin{aligned}
n^{+}+b & =(n+e)+b=n+(e+b)=n+(b+e) \\
& =n+b^{+}=(n+b)^{+}=(b+n)^{+}=b+n^{+}
\end{aligned}$$

which means equation (9) also holds. Therefore, by the principle of mathematical induction, the desired conclusion is proved.
informal_statement:
(2) Commutative Law of Addition For any $a, b \in \boldsymbol{N}$, we have
$$a+b=b+a .$$
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be arbitrary natural numbers. We want to prove that the equality $a + b = b + a$ holds.

The proof proceeds by applying the established theorem for the commutativity of addition on natural numbers, which is available in the Lean mathematical library as `Nat.add_comm`. This theorem states that for any pair of natural numbers, their sum is the same regardless of their order.

By rewriting the expression `a + b` using the `Nat.add_comm` theorem, we directly obtain `b + a`. This makes the left-hand side of our goal identical to the right-hand side, thus completing the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (2) Commutative Law of Addition For any $a, b \in \boldsymbol{N}$, we have
$$a+b=b+a .$$
 -/
theorem algebra_5633
(a b : ℕ) : a + b = b + a := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_5633
(a b : ℕ) : a + b = b + a := by
  rw [Nat.add_comm]

soln_description:
7. Proof: Any integer $a$ can be written in the form
$$a=12 n+b$$

where $n$ is an integer, and $1 \leqslant b \leqslant 12$. If $2 \nmid a, 3 \nmid a$, then since $2|12 n, 3| 12 n$, it follows that $2 \nmid b, 3 \nmid b$. Therefore, $b$ can only take the values 1, 5, 7, 11. When $b=1,5,7$, and 11, $a^{2}+23$ are respectively
$$\begin{array}{l}
(12 n+1)^{2}+23=144 n^{2}+24 n+24 \\
(12 n+5)^{2}+23=144 n^{2}+120 n+48 \\
(12 n+7)^{2}+23=144 n^{2}+168 n+72 \\
(12 n+11)^{2}+23=144 n^{2}+264 n+144
\end{array}$$

Each term on the right-hand side of the above four expressions can be divided by 24, so $a^{2}+23$ can be divided by 24.
informal_statement: 7. Prove that if an integer $a$ is not divisible by 2 and 3, then $a^{2}+23$ must be divisible by 24.
informal_proof:
Let $a$ be an integer such that $a$ is not divisible by 2 and not divisible by 3. We want to prove that $a^2 + 23$ is divisible by 24. This is equivalent to showing that $a^2 + 23 \equiv 0 \pmod{24}$, which simplifies to $a^2 \equiv -23 \equiv 1 \pmod{24}$.

Our strategy will be to prove $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$ and $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$ separately. Since 3 and 8 are coprime, these two congruences together imply $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{24}$.

First, we translate the given divisibility conditions into statements about remainders.
1.  The condition that $a$ is not divisible by 2 implies that the remainder of $a$ when divided by 2 is not 0, i.e., $a \pmod 2 \neq 0$.
2.  Similarly, the condition that $a$ is not divisible by 3 implies that $a \pmod 3 \neq 0$.

Now, we analyze the consequences of these conditions for the remainders of $a$ modulo 8 and 3.

**Proving $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$**
Since $a$ is not divisible by 2, $a$ must be odd. Any odd integer, when divided by 8, must have an odd remainder. Thus, the possible remainders of $a$ modulo 8 are 1, 3, 5, or 7. We consider each case:
- If $a \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$, then $a^2 \equiv 1^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$.
- If $a \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$, then $a^2 \equiv 3^2 \equiv 9 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$.
- If $a \equiv 5 \pmod{8}$, then $a^2 \equiv 5^2 \equiv 25 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$.
- If $a \equiv 7 \pmod{8}$, then $a^2 \equiv 7^2 \equiv 49 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$.
In all possible cases, we find that $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$.

**Proving $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$**
Since $a$ is not divisible by 3, its remainder modulo 3 cannot be 0. Thus, the possible remainders of $a$ modulo 3 are 1 or 2. We consider each case:
- If $a \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$, then $a^2 \equiv 1^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$.
- If $a \equiv 2 \pmod{3}$, then $a^2 \equiv 2^2 \equiv 4 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$.
In both possible cases, we find that $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$.

**Combining the results**
We have established that $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$ and $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$.
The first congruence means that $a^2 - 1$ is divisible by 8.
The second congruence means that $a^2 - 1$ is divisible by 3.
Since 3 and 8 are coprime, if $a^2 - 1$ is divisible by both, it must be divisible by their product, $3 \times 8 = 24$.
Therefore, $24 \mid (a^2 - 1)$, which is equivalent to the congruence $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{24}$.

**Final Step**
From $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{24}$, we can conclude the proof. This congruence means there exists an integer $k$ such that $a^2 = 24k + 1$.
Substituting this into the expression $a^2 + 23$, we get:
$a^2 + 23 = (24k + 1) + 23 = 24k + 24 = 24(k + 1)$.
Since $k+1$ is an integer, this shows that $a^2 + 23$ is divisible by 24.
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Prove that if an integer $a$ is not divisible by 2 and 3, then $a^{2}+23$ must be divisible by 24. -/
theorem number_theory_6903
(a : ℤ) (h : ¬(2 ∣ a)) (h' : ¬(3 ∣ a)) : 24 ∣ a^2 + 23 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_6903
(a : ℤ) (h : ¬(2 ∣ a)) (h' : ¬(3 ∣ a)) : 24 ∣ a^2 + 23 := by
  have h1 : a % 2 ≠ 0 := by
    by_contra h2
    have : 2 ∣ a := by
      omega
    contradiction
  have h2 : a % 3 ≠ 0 := by
    by_contra h3
    have : 3 ∣ a := by
      omega
    contradiction
  have h3 : a % 8 = 1 ∨ a % 8 = 3 ∨ a % 8 = 5 ∨ a % 8 = 7 := by
    omega
  have h4 : a % 3 = 1 ∨ a % 3 = 2 := by 
    omega
  have h5 : a^2 % 8 = 1 := by
    rcases h3 with (h | h | h | h) <;> norm_num [pow_two, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod, h]
  have h6 : a^2 % 3 = 1 := by
    rcases h4 with (h | h) <;> norm_num [pow_two, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod, h]
  have h7 : a^2 % 24 = 1 := by
    omega
  omega

soln_description:
## Solution.

We have $2\left(1-\sin ^{2} x\right)+5 \sin x-4=0$ or $2 \sin ^{2} x-5 \sin x+2=0$. Solving this equation as a quadratic equation in terms of $\sin x$, we get $\sin x=2, \varnothing$, or $\sin x=\frac{1}{2}, x=(-1)^{k} \frac{\pi}{6}+\pi k, \quad k \in Z$.

Answer: $\quad x=(-1)^{k} \frac{\pi}{6}+\pi k, \quad k \in Z$.

    ∃ k : ℤ, x = (-1)^k * Real.pi / 6 + k * Real.pi := by

soln_description:
1. **Given Properties and Initial Setup:**
   - The binary operation $\otimes$ is continuous, commutative, and distributive across multiplication.
   - We are given that $2 \otimes 2 = 4$.
   - We need to solve the equation $x \otimes y = x$ for $y$ in terms of $x$ for $x > 1$.

2. **Functional Form of $\otimes$:**
   - Since $\otimes$ is continuous and distributive across multiplication, we can assume a functional form $x \otimes y = x^{f(y)}$.
   - By commutativity, $x \otimes y = y \otimes x$, we also have $x^{f(y)} = y^{f(x)}$.

3. **Solving for $f(x)$:**
   - Given $2 \otimes 2 = 4$, we substitute into the functional form:
     \[
     2^{f(2)} = 4 \implies 2^{f(2)} = 2^2 \implies f(2) = 2.
     \]
   - Assume $f(x) = c \log x$ for some constant $c$. Then:
     \[
     x^{c \log y} = y^{c \log x}.
     \]
   - Taking the natural logarithm on both sides:
     \[
     c \log y \cdot \log x = c \log x \cdot \log y.
     \]
   - This equation holds true for any $x$ and $y$, confirming our assumption.

4. **Determining the Constant $c$:**
   - From $f(2) = 2$, we have:
     \[
     c \log 2 = 2 \implies c = \frac{2}{\log 2}.
     \]

5. **Solving the Equation $x \otimes y = x$:**
   - Substitute $f(y) = \frac{2 \log y}{\log 2}$ into $x \otimes y = x$:
     \[
     x^{\frac{2 \log y}{\log 2}} = x.
     \]
   - Since $x > 1$, we can equate the exponents:
     \[
     \frac{2 \log y}{\log 2} = 1 \implies 2 \log y = \log 2 \implies \log y^2 = \log 2 \implies y^2 = 2 \implies y = \sqrt{2}.
     \]

6. **Verification:**
   - Verify that $x \otimes \sqrt{2} = x$:
     \[
     x \otimes \sqrt{2} = x^{\frac{2 \log \sqrt{2}}{\log 2}} = x^{\frac{2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} \log 2}{\log 2}} = x^1 = x.
     \]
   - This confirms that $y = \sqrt{2}$ satisfies the equation for any $x > 1$.

The final answer is $\boxed{\sqrt{2}}$.
informal_statement: Let $\otimes$ be a binary operation that takes two positive real numbers and returns a positive real number.  Suppose further that $\otimes$ is continuous, commutative $(a\otimes b=b\otimes a)$, distributive across multiplication $(a\otimes(bc)=(a\otimes b)(a\otimes c))$, and that $2\otimes 2=4$.  Solve the equation $x\otimes y=x$ for $y$ in terms of $x$ for $x>1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $\otimes$ be a binary operation that takes two positive real numbers and returns a positive real number.  Suppose further that $\otimes$ is continuous, commutative $(a\otimes b=b\otimes a)$, distributive across multiplication $(a\otimes(bc)=(a\otimes b)(a\otimes c))$, and that $2\otimes 2=4$.  Solve the equation $x\otimes y=x$ for $y$ in terms of $x$ for $x>1$. -/
theorem algebra_35858 {f : ℝ → ℝ → ℝ}
  (hf : Continuous f)
  (hpos : ∀ x y, 0 < x → 0 < y → 0 < f x y)
  (hcomm : ∀ x y, f x y = f y x)
  (hmul : ∀ x y z, f x (y * z) = f x y * f x z)
  (h22 : f 2 2 = 4) :
  ∀ x > 1, f x (x * (x - 1) / 2) = x := by

soln_description:
11. (1) For any $n(0 \leqslant n \leqslant m)$, take
$$
x_{1}=m, x_{2}=0, \alpha=\frac{n}{m} \in[0,1] \text {. }
$$

Since $f(x)$ is a $C$ function on $\mathbf{R}$, $a_{n}=f(n)$, and $a_{0}=0, a_{m}=2 m$, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{n}=f(n)=f\left(\alpha x_{1}+(1-\alpha) x_{2}\right) \\
\leqslant \alpha f\left(x_{1}\right)+(1-\alpha) f\left(x_{2}\right)=\frac{n}{m} \times 2 m=2 n .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $S_{f}=a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{m}$
$$
\leqslant 2(1+2+\cdots+m)=m^{2}+m \text {. }
$$

We can prove that $f(x)=2 x$ is a $C$ function, and it makes $a_{n}=$ $2 n(n=0,1, \cdots, m)$ all hold. In this case,
$$
S_{f}=m^{2}+m \text {. }
$$

In summary, the maximum value of $S_{f}$ is $m^{2}+m$.
(2) Assume $f(x)$ is a $C$ function on $\mathbf{R}$.
If there exists $mf(n)$, let $x_{1}=n, x_{2}=n-T$, $\alpha=1-\frac{n-m}{T}$, a contradiction can also be derived.
Therefore, $f(x)$ is a constant function on $[0, T)$.
Since $f(x)$ is a periodic function with period $T$, $f(x)$ is a constant function on $\mathbf{R}$, which contradicts the fact that the smallest positive period of $f(x)$ is $T$.
Hence, $f(x)$ is not a $C$ function on $\mathbf{R}$.
informal_statement:
11. (15 points) Let $f(x)$ be a function defined on the domain $D$. If for any real number $\alpha \in(0,1)$ and any two numbers $x_{1}, x_{2}$ in $D$, it always holds that
$$
f\left(\alpha x_{1}+(1-\alpha) x_{2}\right) \leqslant \alpha f\left(x_{1}\right)+(1-\alpha) f\left(x_{2}\right),
$$
then $f(x)$ is called a $C$ function defined on $D$.
(1) Given that $f(x)$ is a $C$ function on $\mathbf{R}$, and $m$ is a given positive integer. Let $a_{n}=f(n)(n=0,1, \cdots, m)$, and $a_{0}=0, a_{m}=2 m$, and denote $S_{f}=a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{m}$. For any function $f(x)$ that satisfies the conditions, try to find the maximum value of $S_{f}$.
(2) If $f(x)$ is a function defined on $\mathbf{R}$ with the smallest positive period $T$, prove that $f(x)$ is not a $C$ function on $\mathbf{R}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- 11. (15 points) Let $f(x)$ be a function defined on the domain $D$. If for any real number $\alpha \in(0,1)$ and any two numbers $x_{1}, x_{2}$ in $D$, it always holds that
$$
f\left(\alpha x_{1}+(1-\alpha) x_{2}\right) \leqslant \alpha f\left(x_{1}\right)+(1-\alpha) f\left(x_{2}\right),
$$
then $f(x)$ is called a $C$ function defined on $D$.
(1) Given that $f(x)$ is a $C$ function on $\mathbf{R}$, and $m$ is a given positive integer. Let $a_{n}=f(n)(n=0,1, \cdots, m)$, and $a_{0}=0, a_{m}=2 m$, and denote $S_{f}=a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{m}$. For any function $f(x)$ that satisfies the conditions, try to find the maximum value of $S_{f}$.
(2) If $f(x)$ is a function defined on $\mathbf{R}$ with the smallest positive period $T$, prove that $f(x)$ is not a $C$ function on $\mathbf{R}$. -/
theorem algebra_311643 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ α ∈ Set.Ioo 0 1, ∀ x y, f (α * x + (1 - α) * y) ≤ α * f x + (1 - α) * f y)
  (m : ℕ) (hm : 0 < m) (a : ℕ → ℝ) (ha : ∀ n, a n = f n) (ha0 : a 0 = 0) (ham : a m = 2 * m)
  (S : ℝ) (hS : S = ∑ i in range m, a (i + 1)) :
  S ≤ m ^ 2 + m := by

soln_description:
【Analysis】Since the sum of three natural numbers $A, B, C$ is 111, and the average of $A, B$ is 31, the sum of $A, B$ is $31 \times 2=62$. Therefore, $C=111-62=49$. Also, since the average of $A, C$ is 37, $B=111-37 \times 2=37$. Then, using the method of finding the average, we can find the average of $B, C$.

【Solution】Solution: $C=111-31 \times 2=49$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
B= & 111-37 \times 2=37, \\
& (49+37) \div 2, \\
= & 86 \div 2, \\
= & 43
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: The average of $B, C$ is 43.
Therefore, the correct choice is: $C$.
informal_statement:
2. (10 points) The sum of three natural numbers $A$, $B$, and $C$ is 111. It is known that the average of $A$ and $B$ is 31, and the average of $A$ and $C$ is 37. What is the average of $B$ and $C$ ( )
A. 34
B. 37
C. 43
D. 68
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. (10 points) The sum of three natural numbers $A$, $B$, and $C$ is 111. It is known that the average of $A$ and $B$ is 31, and the average of $A$ and $C$ is 37. What is the average of $B$ and $C$ ( )
A. 34
B. 37
C. 43
D. 68 -/
theorem algebra_204862 {A B C : ℕ} (h₀ : A + B + C = 111) (h₁ : (A + B) / 2 = 31) (h₂ : (A + C) / 2 = 37) :
    (B + C) / 2 = 43 := by

soln_description:
One, transform the original equation to
$$
2^{2}+\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right) \times 2+\left(a^{3} b-a b^{3}\right)=0 \text {. }
$$

Let $2=x$, then
$$
x^{2}+\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right) x+\left(a^{3} b-a b^{3}\right)=0 \text {. }
$$

Considering the above equation as a quadratic equation in $x$, by the quadratic formula we get $x=-b^{2}-a b$ or $x=-a^{2}+a b$.
Thus, $2=-b^{2}-a b$ or $2=-a^{2}+a b$.
From $2=-b^{2}-a b$ and $b \neq 0$, we get
$$
a=-b-\frac{2}{b} \text {. }
$$

According to equation (1), since $a$ and $b$ are integers, $\frac{2}{b}$ must be an integer, hence $b= \pm 1$ or $\pm 2$.
When $b=1$, $a=-3$; when $b=-1$, $a=3$;
When $b=2$, $a=-3$; when $b=-2$, $a=3$.
From $2=-a^{2}+a b$ and $a \neq 0$, we get $b=a+\frac{2}{a}$.
Similarly, we get
When $a=1$, $b=3$; when $a=-1$, $b=-3$;
When $a=2$, $b=3$; when $a=-2$, $b=-3$.
Therefore, the original equation has 8 integer solutions:
informal_statement: One, (20 points) Find all integer solutions to the equation $a^{3} b-a b^{3}+2 a^{2}+2 b^{2}+4=0$.
Given that the value of $\frac{x-1}{1-\dfrac{x-1}{x}}$ is $-\frac{1}{4}$, then $x=$ ___          ___ .
informal_proof:
Let $x$ be a real number such that $x \neq 0$, $x \neq 1$, and $\frac{x-1}{1-\frac{x-1}{x}} = -\frac{1}{4}$. We aim to show that $x = \frac{1}{2}$.

First, we simplify the complex fraction on the left-hand side of the given equation. The denominator of the main fraction is $1 - \frac{x-1}{x}$. We can combine these terms over a common denominator:
$$ 1 - \frac{x-1}{x} = \frac{x}{x} - \frac{x-1}{x} = \frac{x - (x-1)}{x} = \frac{1}{x} $$
This step is valid because our initial hypothesis states that $x \neq 0$.

Substituting this back into the original expression, we get:
$$ \frac{x-1}{1-\frac{x-1}{x}} = \frac{x-1}{1/x} $$
Since $x \neq 0$, we can multiply the numerator by the reciprocal of the denominator:
$$ \frac{x-1}{1/x} = (x-1) \cdot x = x^2 - x $$
Thus, we have shown that for $x \neq 0$ and $x \neq 1$, the expression simplifies to $x^2 - x$.

Now, we substitute this simplified expression back into the original given equation:
$$ x^2 - x = -\frac{1}{4} $$
This is a quadratic equation. To solve for $x$, we can rearrange the terms to form a perfect square. By adding $\frac{1}{4}$ to both sides, we obtain:
$$ x^2 - x + \frac{1}{4} = 0 $$
The left-hand side is the expansion of $(x - \frac{1}{2})^2$. So, the equation becomes:
$$ \left(x - \frac{1}{2}\right)^2 = 0 $$
For the square of a real number to be zero, the number itself must be zero. Therefore, we can conclude that:
$$ x - \frac{1}{2} = 0 $$
Finally, adding $\frac{1}{2}$ to both sides yields the desired result:
$$ x = \frac{1}{2} $$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given that the value of $\frac{x-1}{1-\dfrac{x-1}{x}}$ is $-\frac{1}{4}$, then $x=$ ___          ___ . -/
theorem algebra_2687 {x : ℝ} (hx : x ≠ 0 ∧ x ≠ 1) (h : (x - 1) / (1 - (x - 1) / x) = -1 / 4) :
    x = 1 / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_2687 {x : ℝ} (hx : x ≠ 0 ∧ x ≠ 1) (h : (x - 1) / (1 - (x - 1) / x) = -1 / 4) :
    x = 1 / 2 := by
  have h1 : x ≠ 0 := hx.1
  have h2 : x ≠ 1 := hx.2

  have hsimp : (x - 1) / (1 - (x - 1) / x) = x ^ 2 - x := by
    have h3 : x ≠ 0 := h1
    have h4 : x - 1 ≠ 0 := by intro h5; apply h2; linarith
    field_simp [h3, h4]
    <;> ring

  rw [hsimp] at h

  have h_eq : (x - 1/2)^2 = 0 := by
    nlinarith
  
  have h_zero : x - 1/2 = 0 := by
    rw [sq_eq_zero_iff] at h_eq 
    exact h_eq
  
  linarith

/- 9、(16 points) In the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$, it is known that $a_{1}=1, a_{2}=\frac{1}{4}$, and $a_{n+1}=\frac{(n-1) a_{n}}{n-a_{n}}(n=2,3, \cdots)$  
(1) Find the general term formula of the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$  
(2) Prove: For all $n \in \mathbb{N}^{*}$, $\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{2}<\frac{7}{6}$. -/
theorem algebra_107521 {a : ℕ → ℝ} (ha1 : a 1 = 1) (ha2 : a 2 = 1 / 4)
    (han : ∀ n ≥ 2, a (n + 1) = (n - 1) * a n / (n - a n)) :
    (∀ n ≥ 1, ∑ k in Finset.Icc 1 n, (a k)^2 < 7 / 6) := by

/- 15. Prove that if $0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{\pi}{2}$, then:
(1) $1-\cos x \leqslant \frac{x^{2}}{2}$;
(2) $x \cos x \leqslant \sin x \leqslant x \cos \frac{x}{2}$. -/
theorem inequalities_139961 (x : ℝ) (hx : x ∈ Icc 0 (π/2)) :
    1 - cos x ≤ x^2 / 2 ∧ x * cos x ≤ sin x ∧ sin x ≤ x * cos (x / 2) := by

soln_description:
The last digit of the smallest number $n_{1}$ is $a$, the second last is $b$ and so on: $n_{1}=$...edcba.

Because of 2, $n$ must be divisible by $5 \cdot 8=40$, meaning $a=0$ and $b$ is even. If $n_{1}$ were a 5-digit number, then $n_{1}=359 b 0$ would have to be true.

Even with any permutation of the digits 3, 5, and 9, $b$ could only be 2 or 6 due to the divisibility of $n_{1}$ by 8 (all three numbers 3, 5, and 9 are odd). However, the cross sum would not be divisible by 3 in that case, so $n_{1}$ must be at least 6 digits long. The smallest 6th digit would be 1, provided that a corresponding $b$ ($b=2$ or $b=6$) exists. In fact, the cross sum of $n_{1}=1359 b 0$ is divisible by 3 for $b=6$. This leads to $n_{1}=135960$.

The remaining sought digits result from permutations of the digits 3, 5, and 9, as the given conditions are not violated:

$$
n_{2}=139560 ; n_{3}=153960 ; n_{4}=159360 ; n_{5}=193560 ; n_{6}=195360
$$
informal_statement:
## Task 29/68

Determine the smallest six natural numbers with the following properties:

1. Each number consists of at least the digits 3, 5, and 9, placed at any position and in any order.
2. Each number is divisible by at least 3, 5, and 8.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 29/68

Determine the smallest six natural numbers with the following properties:

1. Each number consists of at least the digits 3, 5, and 9, placed at any position and in any order.
2. Each number is divisible by at least 3, 5, and 8. -/
theorem number_theory_150316 :
    IsLeast {n | n ≥ 100000 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 3 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 5 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 9 ∧ 3 ∣ n ∧ 5 ∣ n ∧ 8 ∣ n} 135960 ∧
    IsLeast {n | n > 135960 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 3 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 5 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 9 ∧ 3 ∣ n ∧ 5 ∣ n ∧ 8 ∣ n} 139560 ∧
    IsLeast {n | n > 139560 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 3 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 5 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 9 ∧ 3 ∣ n ∧ 5 ∣ n ∧ 8 ∣ n} 153960 ∧
    IsLeast {n | n > 153960 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 3 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 5 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 9 ∧ 3 ∣ n ∧ 5 ∣ n ∧ 8 ∣ n} 159360 ∧
    IsLeast {n | n > 159360 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 3 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 5 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 9 ∧ 3 ∣ n ∧ 5 ∣ n ∧ 8 ∣ n} 193560 ∧
    IsLeast {n | n > 193560 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 3 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 5 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).contains 9 ∧ 3 ∣ n ∧ 5 ∣ n ∧ 8 ∣ n} 195360 := by

soln_description:
[Proof 1] Suppose the quartic polynomial $x^{4}+2 x^{2}+2 x+2$ can be factored into the product of $x^{2}+a x+b$ and $x^{2}+c x+d$, then
$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{4}+2 x^{2}+2 x+2 \\
= & \left(x^{2}+a x+b\right)\left(x^{2}+c x+d\right) \\
= & x^{4}+(a+c) x^{3}+(b+a c+d) x^{2}+(b c+a d) x+b d .
\end{aligned}
$$

Their corresponding coefficients are equal, i.e.,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a+c=0, \\
b+a c+d=2, \\
b c+a d=2, \\
b d=2 .
\end{array}
$$

From (4), we get that $b$ and $d$ are one odd and one even, without loss of generality, let $b$ be odd (actually $\pm$ 1), and $d$ be even (actually $\pm 2$).

At this point, from (3) we get $b c=2-a d$. The right side is even, while the left side's factor $b$ is odd, so $c$ must be even.

Now consider (2), given that $b$ is odd, and $c$ and $d$ are even, we have $b+a c+d$ is odd, but 2 is even, so
$$
b+a c+d=2
$$

does not hold.
Therefore, the quartic polynomial $x^{4}+2 x^{2}+2 x+2$ cannot be factored into the product of $x^{2}+a x+b$ and $x^{2}+c x+d$.
[Proof 2] By Eisenstein's criterion:
For an integer polynomial
$$
f(x)=a_{0} x^{n}+a_{1} x^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{n-1} x+a_{n} .
$$

If there exists a prime number $p$ such that the leading coefficient $a_{0}$ is not divisible by $p$, all other coefficients are divisible by $p$, but the constant term is not divisible by $p^{2}$, then $f(x)$ cannot be factored into the product of two lower-degree integer polynomials.
Let
$$
f(x)=x^{4}+2 x^{2}+2 x+2 .
$$

Then there is a prime number
$$
p=2 \text {, }
$$
$2 \nmid 1$ (the coefficient of $x^{4}$).
$2 \mid 2$ and $2^{2} \nmid$ (the constant term).

Thus, $x^{4}+2 x^{2}+2 x+2$ cannot be factored into the product of two quadratic trinomials.
informal_statement:
7.25 Prove that the polynomial $x^{4}+2 x^{2}+2 x+2$ cannot be factored into the product of two quadratic trinomials with integer coefficients $a, b, c, d$, namely $x^{2}+a x+b$ and $x^{2}+c x+d$.
(Hungarian Mathematical Olympiad, 1922)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7.25 Prove that the polynomial $x^{4}+2 x^{2}+2 x+2$ cannot be factored into the product of two quadratic trinomials with integer coefficients $a, b, c, d$, namely $x^{2}+a x+b$ and $x^{2}+c x+d$.
(Hungarian Mathematical Olympiad, 1922) -/
theorem algebra_200274 (f : Polynomial ℤ) (hf : f = X ^ 4 + 2 * X ^ 2 + 2 * X + 2) :
    ¬∃ a b c d : ℤ, f = (X ^ 2 + a * X + b) * (X ^ 2 + c * X + d) := by

soln_description:
[Proof] Without loss of generality, assume $0 \leqslant x_{1} < x_{2} \leqslant 1$ and $x_{2} - x_{1} > \frac{1}{2}$. From $f(0)=f(1)=0$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|f\left(x_{2}\right)-f\left(x_{1}\right)\right| & =\left|f\left(x_{2}\right)-f(1)+f(0)-f\left(x_{1}\right)\right| \\
& \leqslant\left|f\left(x_{2}\right)-f(1)\right|+\left|f(0)-f\left(x_{1}\right)\right| \\
& <1-x_{2}+x_{1} \\
& =1-\left|x_{2}-x_{1}\right|<\frac{1}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement: 9・104 Let $f(x)$ be defined on $[0,1]$ and $f(0)=f(1)=0$. If for any different $x_{1}, x_{2} \in[0,1]$, we have $| f\left(x_{2}\right)-f\left(x_{1}\right)|<| x_{2}-x_{1} |$, prove that $\left|f\left(x_{2}\right)-f\left(x_{1}\right)\right|<\frac{1}{2}$.
